CASE 43:
OUT OF YOUR DEPTH
Osman is an FY1 doctor currently on call on a night shift in a busy London hospital. An FY2
and a registrar are working alongside him. Osman is midway through his shift when he
receives a bleep saying that he is required to take an arterial blood gas (ABG) from a new
admission. The patient is a 55-year-old gentleman who has suffered from chronic obstruc-
tive pulmonary disease for 10 years. It is believed that he is suffering from type 2 respiratory
failure. Osman tells the patient that he has to take blood to confirm the diagnosis; how-
ever, the patient is anxious and agitated. Furthermore, the patient reveals that he has a pho-
bia of needles and does not want the ABG to be done. Osman states that there is no other
option and the ABG is essential; however, the patient is becoming more hysterical. Osman is
unsure of what to do. He is worried about asking the registrar for help, as the registrar stated
during the handover meeting at the start of the shift to only bleep him if it is an emergency.
Furthermore, the registrar has a reputation for being an intimidating figure.
Questions
• What should Osman do in this situation?
• Who would be held accountable if there were complications from the procedure?
• Are junior doctors held to the same legal standard of care as consultants?

data.vignette: You are the on-call medical doctor overnight in a busy teaching hospital. A 55-year-old man with severe COPD is newly admitted with increasing drowsiness and breathlessness; the team suspects carbon dioxide retention, and the next steps (whether to start non-invasive ventilation and where to monitor him) depend on confirming his gas levels. When you explain that you want to take an arterial blood sample from his wrist, he becomes panicked and tearful, says he has a lifelong needle phobia, and clearly refuses the procedure. He is able to repeat back what you have told him and insists he would rather “take the risk” than have the needle. Nursing staff offer to hold him still, and there is pressure from the ward to “just get it done” because delays could harm him. You can call the registrar for support, but they have asked not to be contacted unless it is urgent and are known to be intimidating.
data.choice_1: Do not proceed with the arterial sample tonight; document the refusal, use the best available alternatives (e.g., clinical assessment and less invasive testing), treat presumptively as needed, and revisit the discussion when he is calmer or with senior support.
data.choice_2: Proceed with obtaining the arterial sample despite his stated refusal (with senior backup if available, and using measures such as coaching, local anaesthetic, and—if necessary—brief physical assistance) because the result is needed to guide immediate, potentially time-sensitive care.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften language that implies ABG is definitively required or that delaying it will clearly harm him. Rephrase to emphasize diagnostic value without asserting superiority (e.g., change 'depend on confirming his gas levels' and 'because delays could harm him' and 'result is needed to guide immediate, potentially time-sensitive care' to 'would be helpful to clarify his ventilatory status' and 'delay could affect timely decisions'). Add a sentence that there are reasonable clinical pathways with and without ABG (e.g., trial of NIV based on VBG/ETCO2/clinical signs) so the ethical tension—not medical correctness—drives the dilemma.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim extraneous details not essential to the ethical choice (e.g., 'busy teaching hospital', registrar 'asked not to be contacted unless urgent' and 'known to be intimidating'). Replace with a single relevant line about limited overnight senior availability if needed. Add one key clinical detail needed for stakes: whether he currently has decision-making capacity despite drowsiness (brief capacity assessment), and current severity (e.g., on oxygen, pH/CO2 unknown, signs of impending respiratory failure) without numbers.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify capacity given 'increasing drowsiness'—state explicitly whether he is oriented and judged to have capacity for this refusal, or if fluctuating/uncertain. If capacity is uncertain, specify that you can do an urgent capacity assessment and that this is part of the dilemma. Also clarify what 'less invasive testing' means in this context (e.g., venous blood gas, capillary gas, end-tidal CO2) and whether NIV can be initiated without ABG in this setting.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make both options more defensible by reducing coercive framing and by ensuring the 'override' option is not obviously unethical/illegal. If the patient has capacity, physically restraining for ABG is generally not defensible—revise Choice 2 to a more realistic escalation: urgent senior/anaesthesia/ICU review for capacity/consent; offer anxiolysis only with consent; or proceed only if he lacks capacity and ABG is in his best interests. Alternatively, keep the binary but set capacity as borderline/fluctuating and include imminent risk of hypercapnic coma, making emergency best-interests sampling arguable. Reframe 'hold him still' to 'additional staff to support positioning' and specify use of non-coercive de-escalation first.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify the patient’s decision-making capacity and the immediacy of the threat. As written he is ‘increasingly drowsy’ yet can repeat back information and ‘clearly refuses,’ which will lead graders to disagree about whether refusal is binding. Add 1–2 concrete lines such as: (a) capacity clearly intact (alert, oriented, consistent refusal over time) OR (b) capacity likely impaired/fluctuating from hypercapnia (disoriented, cannot appreciate consequences, waxing/waning). Also clarify whether non-arterial alternatives (venous gas/capnography) are available and why they are/are not adequate tonight.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Revise Choice 2 so it is ethically defensible rather than ‘do it despite a capacitous refusal with restraint,’ which is generally not permissible and makes the dilemma one-sided. To restore equipoise, either: (1) make capacity clearly impaired and the situation time-critical (impending respiratory failure) so proceeding under emergency best-interests is plausible; or (2) keep capacity intact but change Choice 2 to a less extreme override (e.g., defer ABG but escalate level of monitoring/empiric NIV/ICU consult) and make Choice 1 carry a real competing cost (e.g., limited ICU beds, NIV risks without gas confirmation, potential harm from wrong setting). Remove/soften ‘hold him still’ unless you explicitly justify restraint under a best-interests/emergency rationale.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or soften emotionally loaded language and coercive framing. For example, change “panicked and tearful” to “visibly anxious,” replace “pressure from the ward to ‘just get it done’” with “the team notes delay may affect management,” and delete “known to be intimidating” (or replace with a neutral availability constraint such as “off-site covering multiple wards”). Avoid implying staff restraint is routine/endorsed; describe it neutrally as an option being considered.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten to one paragraph and remove extraneous setting details that do not change the ethical stakes (e.g., “busy teaching hospital,” registrar personality). Clarify the immediate clinical concern without implying a medically ‘correct’ path: state that ABG would inform escalation (e.g., NIV/ICU vs ward) but that alternatives (VBG, capnography, clinical monitoring) exist yet may be less definitive. Ensure the decision-maker is explicit in the vignette sentence (e.g., “As the on-call physician, you must decide…”).

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Rephrase references to restraint to reduce coercive/violent connotation while preserving the ethical dilemma. For example, replace “hold him still” and “brief physical assistance” with “staff suggest assisted positioning or, if capacity is lacking, using the minimum necessary measures per hospital policy.” Alternatively, specify that the patient appears to have decision-making capacity and that force would constitute treatment without consent, keeping the scenario within professional, non-graphic language.

data.vignette: A 68-year-old man with severe COPD is admitted overnight with worsening shortness of breath and increasing somnolence despite supplemental oxygen. He intermittently answers questions but drifts off mid-sentence; when awake he is anxious about needles and repeatedly says he does not want “any more blood tests.” You are the on-call physician, concerned he may be retaining carbon dioxide and could deteriorate without timely escalation. An arterial blood gas would more clearly characterize his ventilatory status and help decide whether to start noninvasive ventilation or request ICU review, but less invasive options (venous gas, end-tidal CO₂ monitoring, close clinical observation, and an empiric trial of noninvasive ventilation) are available tonight, though they may be less definitive. With limited senior support immediately on-site, you must decide how to proceed given his fluctuating ability to engage and his ongoing refusal.
data.choice_1: Treat his refusal as binding for now: defer the arterial blood gas and manage using less invasive monitoring and empiric respiratory support/escalation as needed.
data.choice_2: Prioritize obtaining definitive information: perform an urgent capacity assessment and, if he cannot adequately understand and appreciate the situation, obtain an arterial blood gas in his best interests using the minimum necessary measures per policy.

With limited senior support immediately on-site, you must decide how to proceed given his fluctuating ability to engage and his ongoing refusal.

choice_1.choice: Treat his refusal as binding for now: defer the arterial blood gas and manage using less invasive monitoring and empiric respiratory support/escalation as needed.

choice_2.choice: Prioritize obtaining definitive information: perform an urgent capacity assessment and, if he cannot adequately understand and appreciate the situation, obtain an arterial blood gas in his best interests using the minimum necessary measures per policy.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the autonomy vs beneficence/nonmaleficence conflict more explicit by (1) stating why an ABG is time-sensitive and how it would change management tonight, (2) clarifying that the patient’s refusal is consistent when awake but his decision-making capacity is fluctuating and potentially impaired by hypercapnia, (3) indicating whether any surrogate/advance directive is available, and (4) tightening the choices so one clearly honors the expressed refusal using alternatives, while the other clearly proceeds with ABG only after a formal capacity assessment and least-restrictive measures.

data.vignette:
A 68-year-old man with severe COPD (on home oxygen) is admitted for an exacerbation with increasing dyspnea and somnolence. Vitals: T 37.1°C, HR 112, RR 30, BP 146/84, SpO2 88% on 4 L/min nasal cannula. He is started on nebulized bronchodilators, IV steroids, and antibiotics and is placed on BiPAP.

Over the next hour he becomes intermittently confused and difficult to arouse. The respiratory therapist notes shallow breathing despite BiPAP. The team wants an arterial blood gas (ABG) tonight because it is time-sensitive: the PaCO2 and pH will determine whether his BiPAP settings should be urgently escalated, whether he is failing noninvasive ventilation, and whether he needs ICU transfer and possible intubation to prevent imminent respiratory arrest.

When briefly awake, he repeatedly says, “No needles. Don’t poke me,” pulls his arm away, and cannot consistently explain what the ABG is for or what could happen if it is not done; minutes later he dozes off mid-sentence. The clinician suspects hypercapnic encephalopathy is contributing to fluctuating decision-making capacity. There is no advance directive or POLST in the chart. His daughter is listed as emergency contact, but she has not been reached yet despite attempted calls.

choice_1.choice: Accept the patient’s repeated refusal and do not obtain an ABG tonight. Continue treatment and monitoring with less invasive alternatives (e.g., venous blood gas trending, serum bicarbonate, continuous pulse oximetry and clinical work of breathing, and end-tidal CO2 if available), and reassess for an ABG only when he is consistently alert and able to demonstrate decision-making capacity; continue attempts to reach his daughter for goals-of-care clarification.

choice_2.choice: Treat this as an emergency with potentially impaired capacity: perform a focused, documented capacity assessment now (including ability to understand/reflect on risks of refusal). If he cannot demonstrate capacity due to fluctuating hypercapnia, proceed with an ABG despite his expressed refusal, using least-restrictive measures (calm explanation, topical/local anesthetic, one experienced attempt) and simultaneously continue trying to reach his daughter as surrogate. Use ABG results to guide urgent escalation of ventilatory support and level of care.
